import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Good pronunciation is the key to being understood in Portuguese‚Äîand to understanding your partner when they speak naturally. This guide covers everything you need to know to sound more confident and authentic in Portuguese.

## The Portuguese Alphabet: Getting Started

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Como se pronuncia?"
  translation="How do you pronounce it?"
  pronunciation="KOH-moo see proh-NOON-see-ah"
  context="Ask your partner this whenever you encounter a new word!"
/>

The Portuguese alphabet has 26 letters, the same as English. However, many letters are pronounced differently, and Portuguese has sounds that don't exist in English at all.

## Vowels: The Heart of Portuguese

Portuguese vowels are more complex than English ones, especially because of nasal sounds.

### Open Vowels

<VocabCard
  word="A"
  translation="like 'a' in 'father'"
  pronunciation="ah"
  example="Amor (love) - ah-MOR"
  exampleTranslation="Love"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="E (open)"
  translation="like 'e' in 'bed'"
  pronunciation="eh"
  example="Caf√© (coffee) - kah-FEH"
  exampleTranslation="Coffee"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="O (open)"
  translation="like 'o' in 'hot'"
  pronunciation="oh"
  example="Av√≥ (grandmother) - ah-VOH"
  exampleTranslation="Grandmother"
/>

### Closed Vowels

<VocabCard
  word="E (closed)"
  translation="like 'e' in 'they' (without the y)"
  pronunciation="ay"
  example="Mesa (table) - MAY-zah"
  exampleTranslation="Table"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="O (closed)"
  translation="like 'o' in 'go' (without the w)"
  pronunciation="oh"
  example="Av√¥ (grandfather) - ah-VOH"
  exampleTranslation="Grandfather"
/>

<CultureTip
  title="Accent Marks Tell the Story"
  flag="üáµüáπ"
>
  Portuguese accent marks aren't decorative‚Äîthey tell you exactly how to pronounce a word. "Av√≥" (grandmother) has an open 'o', while "av√¥" (grandfather) has a closed 'o'. The marks are your pronunciation guides!
</CultureTip>

## Nasal Vowels: The Portuguese Signature Sound

This is what makes Portuguese sound so distinctive. Nasal vowels are produced by letting air flow through both your mouth and nose.

<VocabCard
  word="√É / √ÉO"
  translation="nasal 'a' - air through nose"
  pronunciation="ahng (soft ng)"
  example="P√£o (bread) - POWNG"
  exampleTranslation="Bread"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="√Éo"
  translation="nasal 'ow' sound"
  pronunciation="owng"
  example="Cora√ß√£o (heart) - koh-rah-SOWNG"
  exampleTranslation="Heart"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="√ïes"
  translation="nasal 'oy' sound"
  pronunciation="oysh"
  example="Cora√ß√µes (hearts) - koh-rah-SOYSH"
  exampleTranslation="Hearts"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="√Ée"
  translation="nasal 'ay' sound"
  pronunciation="ayng"
  example="M√£e (mother) - MAYNG"
  exampleTranslation="Mother"
/>

### How to Practice Nasal Sounds

1. Say "song" and notice how the 'ng' resonates in your nose
2. Now try to make that nasal quality on a vowel without the 'g' sound
3. Practice with "p√£o" (bread)‚Äîstart with "pow" then add nasality

<CultureTip
  title="The Nasal Trick"
  flag="üáµüáπ"
>
  Pinch your nose while saying a nasal vowel‚Äîyou should feel vibration and resistance. If the sound comes out the same as without pinching, you're not nasalizing enough!
</CultureTip>

## Consonants: Key Differences from English

### The Letter R

Portuguese 'R' is famously tricky because it has multiple sounds:

<VocabCard
  word="R (beginning/double)"
  translation="like 'h' in 'hot' (Brazil) or guttural (Portugal)"
  pronunciation="varies"
  example="Rua (street) - HOO-ah (Brazil), RROO-ah (Portugal)"
  exampleTranslation="Street"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="R (between vowels)"
  translation="soft, tapped 'r' like Spanish"
  pronunciation="light tap"
  example="Caro (expensive) - KAH-roo"
  exampleTranslation="Expensive"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="R (end of word)"
  translation="often silent or very soft in Brazil"
  pronunciation="varies"
  example="Amor (love) - ah-MOR or ah-MOH"
  exampleTranslation="Love"
/>

### The Letter S

<VocabCard
  word="S (beginning)"
  translation="like English 's'"
  pronunciation="ss"
  example="Sol (sun) - SOHL"
  exampleTranslation="Sun"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="S (between vowels)"
  translation="like 'z'"
  pronunciation="z"
  example="Casa (house) - KAH-zah"
  exampleTranslation="House"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="S (end of syllable)"
  translation="'sh' in Rio/Portugal, 's' elsewhere"
  pronunciation="sh or s"
  example="Festa (party) - FESH-tah (Rio)"
  exampleTranslation="Party"
/>

### Letters That Change Sound

<VocabCard
  word="D before i"
  translation="like 'j' in 'jeans' (Brazil)"
  pronunciation="jee"
  example="Dia (day) - JEE-ah"
  exampleTranslation="Day"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="T before i"
  translation="like 'ch' in 'cheese' (Brazil)"
  pronunciation="chee"
  example="Noite (night) - NOY-chee"
  exampleTranslation="Night"
/>

<CultureTip
  title="Regional Variations"
  flag="üáµüáπ"
>
  The D‚ÜíJ and T‚ÜíCH changes are Brazilian. In Portugal, D and T keep their original sounds. Ask your partner which variety they speak so you can match their pronunciation!
</CultureTip>

## Brazilian vs European Portuguese Pronunciation

The differences are significant enough that learners should be aware:

| Feature | Brazilian | European |
|---------|-----------|----------|
| Vowels | More open, clearer | More reduced, "swallowed" |
| R sound | 'H' sound (initial/double) | Guttural or trilled |
| Unstressed E | Sounds like 'ee' | Often silent |
| De/Te | "Jee/Chee" before 'i' | "De/Te" (unchanged) |
| Overall tempo | Slower, melodic | Faster, compact |

### Brazilian Example

<VocabCard
  word="Muito obrigado"
  translation="Thank you very much"
  pronunciation="MOON-too oh-bree-GAH-doo"
  example="Said with clear vowels and 'too' ending"
  exampleTranslation="Thank you very much (Brazilian style)"
/>

### European Example

<VocabCard
  word="Muito obrigado"
  translation="Thank you very much"
  pronunciation="MWEENT oh-bree-GAH-doo"
  example="Said with reduced vowels and clipped ending"
  exampleTranslation="Thank you very much (European style)"
/>

## The Letters LH and NH

These combinations create sounds that don't exist as written in English:

<VocabCard
  word="LH"
  translation="like 'lli' in 'million'"
  pronunciation="ly"
  example="Filho (son) - FEE-lyoo"
  exampleTranslation="Son"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="NH"
  translation="like 'ny' in 'canyon'"
  pronunciation="ny"
  example="Amanh√£ (tomorrow) - ah-mah-NYAH"
  exampleTranslation="Tomorrow"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Trabalho"
  translation="Work"
  pronunciation="trah-BAH-lyoo"
  example="O trabalho √© dif√≠cil. (The work is difficult.)"
  exampleTranslation="The work is difficult."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Minha"
  translation="My (feminine)"
  pronunciation="MEE-nyah"
  example="Minha casa √© sua casa. (My house is your house.)"
  exampleTranslation="My house is your house."
/>

## Stress Patterns: Where to Put the Emphasis

Portuguese words follow predictable stress patterns:

1. **Words ending in -a, -e, -o, -am, -em**: Stress the second-to-last syllable
2. **Words ending in -i, -u, or consonants**: Stress the last syllable
3. **Words with accent marks**: Stress falls on the accented syllable

<VocabCard
  word="Casa"
  translation="House"
  pronunciation="KAH-zah (stress: KA)"
  example="Stress on the first syllable"
  exampleTranslation="House (with stress on first syllable)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Aqui"
  translation="Here"
  pronunciation="ah-KEE (stress: KI)"
  example="Stress on the last syllable"
  exampleTranslation="Here (with stress on last syllable)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="M√∫sica"
  translation="Music"
  pronunciation="MOO-zee-kah (stress: MU)"
  example="Accent mark shows where stress falls"
  exampleTranslation="Music (with accent showing stress)"
/>

## Common Pronunciation Mistakes to Avoid

### 1. Pronouncing final E like English

<VocabCard
  word="Leite"
  translation="Milk"
  pronunciation="LAY-chee (not 'lay-tee')"
  example="In Brazil, final 'e' often sounds like 'ee'"
  exampleTranslation="Milk (Brazilian pronunciation)"
/>

### 2. Using English R

<VocabCard
  word="Rio"
  translation="River / Rio (city)"
  pronunciation="HEE-oo (not 'ree-oh')"
  example="Initial R is an 'H' sound in Brazil"
  exampleTranslation="River / Rio de Janeiro"
/>

### 3. Forgetting nasalization

<VocabCard
  word="Sim"
  translation="Yes"
  pronunciation="seeng (nasal)"
  example="The final 'M' makes the vowel nasal"
  exampleTranslation="Yes (with nasal pronunciation)"
/>

## Practice Words for Couples

<VocabCard
  word="Beijo"
  translation="Kiss"
  pronunciation="BAY-zhoo"
  example="Me d√° um beijo? (Give me a kiss?)"
  exampleTranslation="Give me a kiss?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Abra√ßo"
  translation="Hug"
  pronunciation="ah-BRAH-soo"
  example="Vem c√°, quero um abra√ßo. (Come here, I want a hug.)"
  exampleTranslation="Come here, I want a hug."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Juntos"
  translation="Together"
  pronunciation="ZHOON-toosh"
  example="Sempre juntos. (Always together.)"
  exampleTranslation="Always together."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Saudade"
  translation="Longing/Missing"
  pronunciation="sow-DAH-jee"
  example="Que saudade de voc√™! (How I miss you!)"
  exampleTranslation="How I miss you!"
/>

<CultureTip
  title="Saudade: The Untranslatable Word"
  flag="üáµüáπ"
>
  "Saudade" is considered one of the hardest words to translate. It's a deep emotional longing for someone or something you love but are separated from. Perfect pronunciation of this word will impress any Portuguese speaker!
</CultureTip>

## Tips for Improving Your Pronunciation

1. **Record yourself** and compare to native speakers
2. **Practice with your partner** daily‚Äîeven 5 minutes helps
3. **Listen to Portuguese music** and sing along
4. **Watch videos with subtitles** to connect sounds with spelling
5. **Use the shadowing technique**: Listen and repeat immediately after native speakers

## Start Speaking Today

Pronunciation improves with practice, and you have the best practice partner possible‚Äîsomeone who loves you and wants to help you succeed. Don't wait until your pronunciation is "perfect." Start speaking Portuguese today, and let your partner gently guide you toward better sounds.

Every word you pronounce correctly is a step closer to their heart.

<CTA
  text="Ready to master Portuguese together?"
  buttonText="Start Learning Now"
/>

A »ôti sƒÉ √Æ»õi ceri scuze cu sinceritate √Æn limba partenerului tƒÉu este esen»õial pentru o rela»õie sƒÉnƒÉtoasƒÉ. √én englezƒÉ, existƒÉ multe modalitƒÉ»õi de a exprima regretul, de la scuze simple la cereri elaborate de iertare.

<PhraseOfDay
  word="I'm sorry"
  translation="√émi pare rƒÉu"
  pronunciation="aim sor-i"
  context="Expresia principalƒÉ pentru scuze √Æn englezƒÉ"
/>

## Scuze de bazƒÉ √Æn EnglezƒÉ

Aceste expresii sunt fundamentale pentru orice conversa»õie √Æn care trebuie sƒÉ √Æ»õi ceri scuze:

<VocabCard
  word="I'm sorry"
  translation="√émi pare rƒÉu"
  pronunciation="aim sor-i"
  example="I'm sorry for being late."
  exampleTranslation="√émi pare rƒÉu cƒÉ am √Ænt√¢rziat."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Please forgive me"
  translation="Te rog sƒÉ mƒÉ ier»õi"
  pronunciation="pliiz for-ghiv mi"
  example="Please forgive me, I didn't mean to hurt you."
  exampleTranslation="Te rog sƒÉ mƒÉ ier»õi, nu am vrut sƒÉ te rƒÉnesc."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="It's my fault"
  translation="E vina mea"
  pronunciation="its mai folt"
  example="It's my fault, I should have listened."
  exampleTranslation="E vina mea, ar fi trebuit sƒÉ ascult."
/>

<CultureTip flag="üá¨üáß" title="Cultura scuzelor">
√én cultura anglo-saxonƒÉ, expresiile sunt adesea mai subtile. 'I'm sorry' poate √Ænsemna at√¢t scuze c√¢t »ôi empatie.
</CultureTip>

## Expresii pentru a cere iertare

C√¢nd ai gre»ôit mai serios, ai nevoie de expresii mai puternice:

| EnglezƒÉ | Rom√¢nƒÉ |
|---------|---------|
| I'm sorry | √émi pare rƒÉu |
| Please forgive me | Te rog sƒÉ mƒÉ ier»õi |
| It's my fault | E vina mea |
| I was wrong | Am gre»ôit |
| Let's make up | Hai sƒÉ ne √ÆmpƒÉcƒÉm |

<VocabCard
  word="I was wrong"
  translation="Am gre»ôit"
  pronunciation="ai woz rong"
  example="I was wrong to say those things."
  exampleTranslation="Am gre»ôit sƒÉ spun acele lucruri."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="I apologize"
  translation="√émi cer scuze"
  pronunciation="ai …ô-pol-…ô-jaiz"
  example="I apologize for my behavior yesterday."
  exampleTranslation="√émi cer scuze pentru comportamentul meu de ieri."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="I take full responsibility"
  translation="√émi asum √Æntreaga responsabilitate"
  pronunciation="ai teik ful ri-spon-si-bil-i-ti"
  example="I take full responsibility for this mistake."
  exampleTranslation="√émi asum √Æntreaga responsabilitate pentru aceastƒÉ gre»ôealƒÉ."
/>

## Expresii de reconciliere

DupƒÉ ce »õi-ai cerut scuze, aceste fraze te ajutƒÉ sƒÉ reconstruie»ôti legƒÉtura:

<VocabCard
  word="Let's make up"
  translation="Hai sƒÉ ne √ÆmpƒÉcƒÉm"
  pronunciation="lets meik ap"
  example="I don't want to fight anymore. Let's make up."
  exampleTranslation="Nu mai vreau sƒÉ ne certƒÉm. Hai sƒÉ ne √ÆmpƒÉcƒÉm."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Can we start over?"
  translation="Putem sƒÉ o luƒÉm de la capƒÉt?"
  pronunciation="k√¶n wi start ou-v…ôr"
  example="Can we start over and forget this happened?"
  exampleTranslation="Putem sƒÉ o luƒÉm de la capƒÉt »ôi sƒÉ uitƒÉm cƒÉ s-a √Ænt√¢mplat?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="I promise to do better"
  translation="Promit sƒÉ mƒÉ comport mai bine"
  pronunciation="ai prom-is tu du bet-…ôr"
  example="I promise to do better in the future."
  exampleTranslation="Promit sƒÉ mƒÉ comport mai bine √Æn viitor."
/>

## Cum sƒÉ accep»õi scuzele cuiva

C√¢nd partenerul tƒÉu √Æ»ôi cere scuze, po»õi rƒÉspunde cu aceste expresii:

| EnglezƒÉ | Rom√¢nƒÉ |
|---------|---------|
| It's okay | E √Æn regulƒÉ |
| I forgive you | Te iert |
| Don't worry about it | Nu-»õi face griji pentru asta |
| Let's move on | SƒÉ mergem mai departe |
| Water under the bridge | ApƒÉ trƒÉitƒÉ (literar: apƒÉ sub pod) |

<VocabCard
  word="I forgive you"
  translation="Te iert"
  pronunciation="ai for-ghiv ju"
  example="I forgive you. Let's not fight anymore."
  exampleTranslation="Te iert. SƒÉ nu ne mai certƒÉm."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Don't worry about it"
  translation="Nu-»õi face griji pentru asta"
  pronunciation="dount wor-i …ô-baut it"
  example="Don't worry about it. Everyone makes mistakes."
  exampleTranslation="Nu-»õi face griji pentru asta. ToatƒÉ lumea gre»ôe»ôte."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Water under the bridge"
  translation="ApƒÉ trƒÉitƒÉ (idiom)"
  pronunciation="wot-…ôr an-d…ôr √∞…ô brij"
  example="It's water under the bridge now. Let's forget it."
  exampleTranslation="E apƒÉ trƒÉitƒÉ acum. SƒÉ uitƒÉm."
/>

## Sfaturi pentru scuze sincere √Æn EnglezƒÉ

1. **Fii specific** ‚Äì Men»õioneazƒÉ exact ce ai fƒÉcut gre»ôit
2. **AratƒÉ empatie** ‚Äì Recunoa»ôte cum s-a sim»õit partenerul tƒÉu
3. **EvitƒÉ scuzele** ‚Äì Nu da vina pe circumstan»õe
4. **OferƒÉ solu»õii** ‚Äì Spune ce vei face diferit pe viitor
5. **DƒÉ-i timp** ‚Äì Nu for»õa iertarea imediatƒÉ

<CultureTip flag="üá∫üá∏" title="Autenticitatea √Æn scuze">
√én cultura englezƒÉ, o scuzƒÉ autenticƒÉ include trei pƒÉr»õi: recunoa»ôterea gre»ôelii, exprimarea regretului »ôi angajamentul de a te schimba. Simplul "sorry" nu este √Æntotdeauna suficient √Æn situa»õii serioase.
</CultureTip>

<CTA />

## Articole conexe

- [Exprimarea emo»õiilor √Æn englezƒÉ](/ro/en/english-expressing-emotions)
- [Fraze romantice √Æn englezƒÉ](/ro/en/english-romantic-phrases-for-every-occasion)

# Russiske udtryk til at m√∏de svigerfor√¶ldre

At m√∏de russiske svigerfor√¶ldre er en betydningsfuld begivenhed. Russisk kultur l√¶gger stor v√¶gt p√• familie, tradition og g√¶stfrihed. Din indsats for at l√¶re nogle russiske s√¶tninger vil blive enormt v√¶rdsat og vise din respekt for deres kultur.

## Kulturel kontekst

I Rusland har svigerfor√¶ldre s√¶rlige navne afh√¶ngigt af dit k√∏n. Hvis du er mand: svigermor er "—Ç—ë—â–∞" (tjoshcha) og svigerfar er "—Ç–µ—Å—Ç—å" (tjest). Hvis du er kvinde: svigermor er "—Å–≤–µ–∫—Ä–æ–≤—å" (svekrov) og svigerfar er "—Å–≤—ë–∫–æ—Ä" (svjokor). Man bruger "–í—ã" (De-formen) og fornavn + patronym til √¶ldre.

## Vigtige s√¶tninger

### 1. –û—á–µ–Ω—å –ø—Ä–∏—è—Ç–Ω–æ —Å –≤–∞–º–∏ –ø–æ–∑–Ω–∞–∫–æ–º–∏—Ç—å—Å—è
**Dansk:** Det er mig en stor forn√∏jelse at m√∏de Dem
**Udtale:** o-chen pri-yat-na s va-mi pa-zna-ko-mi-tsa
**R√•d:** Et fast h√•ndtryk for m√¶nd, let h√•ndkys eller h√•ndtryk for kvinder

### 2. –Ø –º–Ω–æ–≥–æ –æ –≤–∞—Å —Å–ª—ã—à–∞–ª/—Å–ª—ã—à–∞–ª–∞
**Dansk:** Jeg har h√∏rt meget om Dem (mand/kvinde)
**Udtale:** ya mno-ga a vas sly-shal / sly-sha-la
**R√•d:** Viser at din partner taler godt om sin familie

### 3. –ë–æ–ª—å—à–æ–µ —Å–ø–∞—Å–∏–±–æ –∑–∞ –ø—Ä–∏–≥–ª–∞—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ
**Dansk:** Mange tak for invitationen
**Udtale:** bal-sho-ye spa-si-ba za pri-gla-she-ni-ye
**R√•d:** Russere v√¶rds√¶tter oprigtig taknemmelighed

### 4. –Ø –ø—Ä–∏–Ω—ë—Å/–ø—Ä–∏–Ω–µ—Å–ª–∞ –≤–∞–º –Ω–µ–±–æ–ª—å—à–æ–π –ø–æ–¥–∞—Ä–æ–∫
**Dansk:** Jeg har medbragt en lille gave (mand/kvinde)
**Udtale:** ya pri-nyos / pri-nyes-la vam nye-bal-shoy pa-da-rak
**R√•d:** Blomster (ulige antal), chokolade eller god alkohol er passende

### 5. –£ –≤–∞—Å –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤—ã–π –¥–æ–º
**Dansk:** De har et meget smukt hjem
**Udtale:** u vas o-chen kra-si-vy dom
**R√•d:** Russere er stolte af deres hjem

### 6. –ë—ã–ª–æ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –≤–∫—É—Å–Ω–æ
**Dansk:** Det var meget l√¶kkert
**Udtale:** by-la o-chen fkus-na
**R√•d:** Russisk g√¶stfrihed udtrykkes gennem mad - spis godt!

### 7. –Ø –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –ª—é–±–ª—é –≤–∞—à–µ–≥–æ —Å—ã–Ω–∞/–≤–∞—à—É –¥–æ—á—å
**Dansk:** Jeg elsker Deres s√∏n/datter meget
**Udtale:** ya o-chen lyub-lyu va-she-va sy-na / va-shu doch
**R√•d:** Vis dine f√∏lelser med oprigtighed

### 8. –ú—ã –æ—á–µ–Ω—å —Å—á–∞—Å—Ç–ª–∏–≤—ã –≤–º–µ—Å—Ç–µ
**Dansk:** Vi er meget lykkelige sammen
**Udtale:** my o-chen shchas-li-vy vmyes-tye
**R√•d:** Bekr√¶fter forholdets styrke

### 9. –Ø —Ö–æ—Ç–µ–ª –±—ã/—Ö–æ—Ç–µ–ª–∞ –±—ã —É–∑–Ω–∞—Ç—å –≤–∞—Å –ª—É—á—à–µ
**Dansk:** Jeg vil gerne l√¶re Dem bedre at kende (mand/kvinde)
**Udtale:** ya kha-tyel by / kha-tye-la by uz-nat vas luch-she
**R√•d:** Viser √¶gte interesse i familien

### 10. –ú–æ–≥—É —è —á–µ–º-–Ω–∏–±—É–¥—å –ø–æ–º–æ—á—å?
**Dansk:** Kan jeg hj√¶lpe med noget?
**Udtale:** ma-gu ya chem-ni-but pa-moch
**R√•d:** At tilbyde hj√¶lp viser respekt

### 11. –≠—Ç–æ –∑–∞–º–µ—á–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–∞—è —Å–µ–º–µ–π–Ω–∞—è —Ç—Ä–∞–¥–∏—Ü–∏—è
**Dansk:** Det er en vidunderlig familietradition
**Udtale:** e-ta za-mye-cha-tyel-na-ya sye-myey-na-ya tra-di-tsi-ya
**R√•d:** Russere er stolte af deres traditioner

## Yderligere kulturelle tips
